title: Magical Haida Gwaii -- Canada's Galapagos [Photos] [Video]

Haida Gwaii. 
A magical one-of-a-kind destination offering spiritually uplifting adventure in a West-coast wonderland where island-dotted Pacific Ocean waterways and towering lush green and often misty old-growth rainforest are intertwined with a fascinating ancient culture. 
This special place - sometimes described as Canada's Galapagos - offers ample opportunities to see majestic bald eagles soaring from one lofty perch to another, great blue herons standing silently in the shallows, noisy oystercatchers with their carrot-like noses chasing each other madly around rocky shorelines and colorful tufted puffins bobbing for fish in the open water. 
You can also watch in wonder as black bears - unique to this area with their larger jaws and teeth - forage for snacks, amble through alpine meadows and swim across channels; curious harbour seals and Steller sea lions pop up to check you out or bask in the sun at sheltered haulout sites; and orcas (killer whales) glide by you in the water flashing their unmistakable dorsal fins. 
And, of course, it is not uncommon to be gifted with the amazing sight of huge humpback whales as they loudly snort, blow water geysers, acrobatically breach the surface and show off their distinct tails before diving down. 
MUST SEE 
These spectacular marvels and so much more await you in the formerly named Queen Charlotte Islands - featuring the magnificent Gwaii Haanas national park and marine conservation area - which are across Hecate Strait from northern B.C.'s Prince Rupert, 750 km north of Vancouver, and easily accessible by water or air. 
A must-see highlight of Gwaii Haanas is a visit to SGang Gwaay, a sacred village site of the Haida people which has been declared a UNESCO World Heritage site and where Watchmen give insightful tours of the remains of traditional cedar longhouses and carved mortuary poles. 
I recently travelled to Haida Gwaii and went on a fabulous eight-day guided kayaking tour in the southern portion of the Gwaii Haanas National Park Reserve. 
It was an awesome trip that left me feeling like I had escaped the urban trappings and hectic pace of the modern day lifestyle and stepped into a world like no other where you can enjoy a simple and natural way of life. 
Our group - made up of myself, seven wonderful people from across Canada, the U.S. and Germany and our two experienced and knowledgeable guides - enjoyed a veritable feast of wildlife viewing while paddling our way through mind-blowing scenery and were feasted ourselves while camping at various beaches in tents pitched near streams on soft moss-carpeted sections of rainforest. 
Our first evening at Raspberry Cove featured a deer wandering the beach, a black bear foraging for supper on some nearby rocks and a curious seal eyeballing us from the water, which were promising signs of things to come. 
Most days consisted of rising early for coffee and breakfast, taking down our tents and packing up our stuff, and then loading our kayaks to embark on our next adventure, before ending the day by pitching our tents at a new camping location and enjoying a fine dinner and a fire. 
You don't need to be an expert kayaker as the single and double fibreglass sea kayaks are quite stable and easy to manoeuvre and the guides were excellent in demonstrating proper techniques and offering useful paddling tips. 
If you are not averse to camping, the waterproof tents are spacious and the sleeping bags and sleeping pads make for warm and quite comfortable sleeping under the stars. 
NO TOILETS! 
One thing you do need to get used to is the lack of toilets or even outhouses. The inter-tidal flush is the preferred method of human waste disposal and you can either go bidet-style or use toilet paper and burn or pack it out. 
Our group had a blue toilet bag filled with the necessary supplies, including hand sanitizer, which we nicknamed "Steve" and each campsite had a designated bathroom area by the water which we dubbed "Steve Town." 
The paddling - through choppy open sea, narrow inlets with rushing tides and calm, secluded bays - was exceptional and the intense feelings you get while rhythmically gliding through morning mist are almost indescribable. 
The tour encompassed a number of destinations, including the unbelievable SGang Gwaay, the abandoned whaling station at Rose Harbour, a former cannery and saltery site and Burnaby Narrows, a rich intertidal channel where hundreds of marine species are concentrated in a kaleidoscope of various colorful sea stars, anemones, jellyfish, snails, mussels, sea urchins, clams and crabs. 
One of the wildlife highlights happened as we were kayaking from Burnaby Narrows to our nearby campsite. A black bear we had earlier seen on the shore of a small island decided to swim back across right in front of us. It was incredible as we watched it clamber out, shake the water off itself like a big dog and then mosey on its way. 
Some of the best marine life encounters we had on the trip came as we crossed Carpenter Bay and were treated to numerous sightings of humpback whales, including one who breached only 10 to 15 metres away from my kayak. 
I was also lucky enough to be looking behind us later and had the perfect viewing angle as a humpback flashed me its tail fluke while preparing to dive down to the deep. 
Another awe-inspiring sight occurred on our last night when I got up at 2 a.m. and stumbled through the dark to the beach. First, I looked up and was put in my lowly place by the zillion stars twinkling above me. Then, I gazed upon the water and was wonderstruck by the dancing lights caused by bioluminescence, a natural phenomenon caused by chemical reactions in marine organisms. 
It certainly was a trip of a lifetime that I will never forget and I would recommend it highly to everyone. 
There is evidence that the Haida people have lived on Haida Gwaii for more than 12,500 years, with scientists now saying it could be even a thousand years longer, and stories of the fascinating ancient indigenous culture live on at several protected sacred village sites. 
On a recent kayaking trip in the Gwaii Haanas National Park Reserve in the south of Haida Gwaii, I visited SGang Gwaay - a UNESCO World Heritage site - and was enthralled by the Watchmen-led tour of the remains of carved mortuary poles and traditional cedar longhouses. 
The Watchmen live at the five village sites as guardians, to protect their natural and cultural heritage, and our guide, Ken, blew our minds with his vast knowledge of the passed-on-by-mouth legends of his ancestors. 
He explained the way the mortuary poles - a type of totem pole - were built, what they signified, what the various crests on them meant and how the preserved bodies of chiefs would be placed inside grave boxes at the top of them, serving as both a tomb and a headstone. 
According to a Gwaii Haanas visitor guide, there were about 20,000 Haida when Europeans first made contact and the population plummeted as a result of communicable diseases such as smallpox, measles and tuberculosis being introduced by the visitors. By the late 1800s, there were fewer than 600 Haida left on Haida Gwaii. 
SURVIVORS 
The survivors from the southern villages gathered at SGang Gwaay - which means Wailing Island, a name based on a sound created at certain tides when air was forced through a hole in a rock on the island - but eventually they moved northward to join other Haida clans. 
SGang Gwaay represents one of the best examples in the world of a traditional Northwest Coast First Nations village site and the remains of some of its 20 or so longhouses are still evident when you visit. 
Ken explained the intricate way the longhouses at the winter village site were constructed, including the use of plank walls that could be removed and used for other structures during the summer, and how the various rooms were used to put up visitors and host celebrations. 
He also told very interesting stories about his Haida Gwaii ancestors being able to travel long distances by canoe at a time when the seas were much lower than they are today and said they used to trade with people in places as far away as California, Australia and New Zealand. 
People are able to visit SGang Gwaay and the other four village sites from May to September, but only 12 people at a time are allowed on shore and you need to first ask the Watchmen for permission to land. 
FACTS 
* Haida Gwaii, formerly known as the Queen Charlotte Islands, is a group of islands off of the west coast of northern British Columbia. 
* You can get there by either flying to airports at Masset, on Graham Island, or Sandspit, on Moresby Island, or by a six-hour B.C. ferry ride from Prince Rupert. 
* In order to go to the Gwaii Haanas National Park Reserve, you must pay a visitor fee and take an hour-long orientation session. 
* Kayaking tours are only available through licensed tour operators and it costs about $3,000 for an eight-day trip. 
* Parks Canada and Haida Nation publish an online Gwaii Haanas Trip Planner that is full of information and contains a list of licensed operators and links to their websites. It can be accessed through the Parks Canada website at: www.pc.gc.ca
